Award.AbstractNarration:
Particle physics is focused on understanding the most basic building blocks of the Universe and the rules that bind them. The CERN Large Hadron Collider (LHC), located near Geneva, Switzerland is the world's most powerful particle accelerator, able to reach the highest particle energies in a laboratory setting, and a platform for precision studies of the Electroweak interaction.

The Standard Model of particle physics can be challenged using precise measurements of electroweak probes based on the large LHC data samples. This requires a higher level of accuracy and confidence on the inputs used in the analyses and in the interpretation of the results in addition to more advanced analysis techniques. This project provides support for a workshop at the Colegio de Fisica Fundamental e Interdisciplinaria de las Americas (COFI) in San Juan, Puerto Rico that will focus on bringing together particle experimentalists and particle theorists to address the challenges of precision electroweak physics at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) using the current 13 TeV data sample.

Current challenges include reducing uncertainties on the theoretical corrections (both electroweak and Quantum Chromo-dynamics) and the inputs needed to describe proton-proton collisions (parton distribution functions), and subtleties in combining and fitting the electroweak data. These issues must be understood for many of the crucial measurements, like the W and Higgs bosons and top quark masses, the weak mixing angle, di-boson scattering, and rare or forbidden decays of bosons. The workshop will bring relevant experts together to improve our understanding and perform the best possible precision electroweak measurements. A focus will be on the interplay between the various theoretical inputs needed to find deviations, if any, to the expected electroweak observables and the opportunities to exploit measurements to calibrate theoretical predictions.

Discussions between theorists and experimentalists in a workshop setting will lead to an improved understanding, which in turn will lead to more precise electroweak measurements, potentially expanding the reach of the LHC during the next run. This project also aims to support the local scientific community in Puerto Rico and establish significant under-represented group participation. Another important goal is to foster the connections between Puerto Rican researchers abroad and the local community. Several postdocs and graduate students residing abroad will be participating in the workshop. COFI is a member of the UNITWIN/UNESCO Chairs Program, which involves 700 institutions in 116 countries to promote cooperation and networking to enhance institutional capacities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On 16-20 July 2019 we held the -- 1st COFI Workshop on Precision Electroweak Physics -- at the ?Colegio De F?sica Fundamenal E Interdisciplinaria de Las Am?ricas? (COFI) in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The conference was organized by Mayda Velasco (COFI and Northwestern Univ, USA), Josh Bendavid (CERN, Switzerland), Chiara Marriotti (INFN Torino, Italy), Aram Apyan (FNAL, Batavia, IL), Frank Petriello (ANL and Northwestern Univ, USA), and Jose Nieves (Univ. of Puerto Rico, Rio Piedras Campus).

The workshop was a highly successful follow-on to intense ongoing discussions on how to properly pursue high precision electro weak physics, from both the experimental and theoretical point of view, in the post Higgs Boson Discovery Era and the large data samples coming from the Large Hadron Collider. A follow-up meeting is already planned. Our speaker pool was diverse in demographics, geographic and institutional representation from the US, Latin America and Europe. It featured eighteen speakers over four days, bring together both theorists and experimentalists in different areas to improve our understanding and performance of precision measurements:

 1. Precision electroweak calculations in the Standard Model -Ayres Freitas (University of Pittsburgh)

2. Precision electroweak physics with low energy measurements - Jens Erler (IF-UNAM, Mexico)

3. Connecting low and high energies with Effective Field Theories - Gil Paz (Wayne State University)

4. Latest on developments on electroweak fitting programs - Tevong You (University of Cambridge)

5. Probing the Standard Model Effective Field Theory with diboson processes - Viviana Cavaliere (Brookhaven National Lab)

6. New Physics in Drell-Yan at the Z-pole and in High-Mass Tails: Inherent Uncertainties in the Standard Model Effective Field Theory - William Shepherd (Sam Houston State University)

7. Experimental status and challenges on the combination of the Higgs boson data - Andrew Gilbert (CERN)

8. The precision Higgs Frontier - Daniel De Florian (Universidad de Buenos Aires)

9. Jet substructure tools - Kyle Lee (Stonybrook)

10. Parton distributions: the art of solving ill-posed problems - Prof. Stefano Forte (Universit? degli Studi e INFN Milano (IT))

11. Overview of the future of collider physics at the LHC - Jonathan R. Ellis (University of London (GB)

12. Non-perturbative uncertainties on the transverse momentum distribution of electroweak bosons and on the determination of the W boson mass at the LHC - Andrea Signori (Argonne National Laboratory)

13. Measurement of sin2-theta_W at the LHC - Arie Bodek (University of Rochester (US)

14. QCD and QED NNLO corrections to Drell Yan production - Daniel De Florian (Laboratorio de Fisica Teorica Departamento de Fisica)

15. Experimental status of W-mass at the LHC: What is needed and on how to combine the data? - Stefano Camarda (CERN)

16. Electroweak and QCD effects in the W-boson mass determination - Fulvio Piccinini (Universita and INFN (IT))

17. Measurements of the W and Z pT spectra as needed for W mass measurements - Aram Apyan (Fermi National Accelerator Lab. (US))

18. W-Drell Yan measurements relevant for PDF constraints and phenomenology of W helicity - Josh Bendavid (CERN)

The broader impact of these awards is significant: One of our long-term plans is to support the scientific community in PR and have a significant number of female participants in our scientific activities.  Both were achieved. Several Puerto Rican PhD students (2) and postdocs (2), currently based outside PR and working in the field, were identified and financially supported in order to attend the meeting. In addition, a total of six females attended (2 faculty, 1 postdocs, 1 student PhD and 2 undergraduates), where two of them were speakers.

 

In addition, the event help to continue to develop a closer collaboration between COFI, the University of Puerto Rico and the Arecibo Radio Telescope. As in the past, they have benefited from the interaction with scientists being brought to PR by COFI. For example, we organized a VIP visit to the Arecibo Observatory for Prof. John Ellis who came for COFI's EWK workshop. The Arecibo staff had the opportunity to interact with Prof. Ellis who is a versatile. renown theorist and experienced scientific advisor at the international level. At the end of his visit, he gave a public lecture.
